sen.j: 古川 節蔵（ふるかわ せつぞう、幼名・岡本亀五郎。通称・岡本周吉、のち古川節蔵、古川正雄。ペンネーム・岡本博卿など。1837年（天保8年）3月4日） - 1877年（明治10年）4月2日）は、明治期の教育者。
sen.e: Setsuzo HURUKAWA, his childhood name was Kamegoro OKAMOTO.

Setsuzo FURUKAWA (March 4, 1837 - April 2, 1877) was an educator of the Meiji period (childhood name was Kamegoro OKAMOTO; common name was Shukichi OKAMOTO, later changed to Setsuzo FURUKAWA and to Masao FURUKAWA; pen name was Hakukei OKAMOTO and so on).
sen.cmt: 原文の一文が括弧内句点によって数文に分かれていましたのでルールどおりに直します。固有名詞読み間違いがあります。
sen.e: Setsuzo FURUKAWA (March 4, 1837 - April 2, 1877) was an educator of the Meiji period (childhood name was Kamegoro OKAMOTO; common name was Shukichi OKAMOTO, later changed to Setsuzo FURUKAWA and to Masao FURUKAWA; pen name was Hakukei OKAMOTO and so on).

sen.j: 福澤諭吉の弟子として、日本の近代教育の礎を築いた教育者の一人。
sen.e: He was one of the educators who established the foundation of the modern Japanese education as a disciple of Yukichi FUKUZAWA.
He was one of the educators who established the foundation of the modern Japanese education as a disciple of Yukichi FUKUZAWA.
He was one of the educators who established the foundation of the modern Japanese education as a disciple of Yukichi FUKUZAWA.

sen.j: 慶應義塾初代塾長。
sen.e: He was the first principal of the Keio Gijuku school.
He was the first president of Keio Gijuku (an institution of Western learning, present Keio University and Keio Gijuku educational corporation).
sen.cmt: 「慶応義塾」はKeio Gijuku、「塾長」はpresident、慶応ホームページに従います。
sen.e: He was the first president of Keio Gijuku (an institution of Western learning, present Keio University and Keio Gijuku educational corporation).

sen.j: また明治維新には民間人として榎本武揚に加わり戊辰戦争を戦った。
sen.e: During the Meiji Restoration, he joined the army of Takeaki ENOMOTO and participated in the Boshin War.
During the Meiji Restoration, he joined the army led by Takeaki ENOMOTO although he had been just a citizen, and he fought in the Boshin War.
During the Meiji Restoration, he joined the army led by Takeaki ENOMOTO although he had been just a citizen, and he fought in the Boshin War.

sen.j: 広島県西中国山地に奥深い山県郡 (広島県)北広島町生まれ。
sen.e: He was born in Kitahiroshima-cho town, Yamagata County (Hiroshima Prefecture) deep in the Nishichugoku Mountains of Hiroshima Prefecture.
He was born in Kitahiroshima-cho, Yamagata County (Hiroshima Prefecture) deep in the Western Chugoku Mountains of Hiroshima Prefecture.
He was born in Kitahiroshima-cho, Yamagata County (Hiroshima Prefecture) deep in the Western Chugoku Mountains of Hiroshima Prefecture.

sen.j: 庄屋の三男に生まれた。
sen.e: He was the third son of a village headman
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was the third son of a village headman
He was the third son of a village headman

sen.j: 青年期に医学を志し、広島市に出て漢学を学ぶ。
sen.e: He pursued medical science during his adolescence and then moved to Hiroshima City to learn Sinology.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He pursued medical science during his adolescence and then moved to Hiroshima City to learn Sinology.
He pursued medical science during his adolescence and then moved to Hiroshima City to learn Sinology.

sen.j: 1856年（安政3年）、今度は大阪市に出て緒方洪庵の適塾に入門。
sen.e: In 1856, he then moved to Osaka City and joined a school called Tekijuku that was established by Koan OGATA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1856, he moved to Osaka City and entered Teki-juku, a private school established by Koan OGATA.
In 1856, he moved to Osaka City and entered Teki-juku, a private school established by Koan OGATA.

sen.j: 蘭学、兵学を修めた。
sen.e: He learned Western studies and military sciences in the Tekijuku school.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He learned Western studies and military science there.
He learned Western studies and military science there.

sen.j: この頃は岡本周吉と称した。
sen.e: He called himself Shukichi OKAMOTO during this time.
He called himself Shukichi OKAMOTO in those years.
He called himself Shukichi OKAMOTO in those years.

sen.j: 1858年（安政5年）、この適塾で塾長を務めていた福澤諭吉が、中津藩の命令で江戸に蘭学の塾を開くことになり、同窓の中から同行者を募った。
sen.e: In 1858, the principal of Tekijuku, Yukichi FUKUZAWA was ordered by the Nakatsu Domain to open a school for Western studies in Edo and recruited students for the new school.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1858, the president of Teki-juku, Yukichi FUKUZAWA was ordered by the Nakatsu clan to open a school of Western studies in Edo, and recruited company from the alumni.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。福沢が塾長で周吉が学生なので翻訳者はおかしいと判断したと思われますが、周吉と福沢は当時にはよくある「同窓」の関係です。
sen.e: In 1858, the president of Teki-juku, Yukichi FUKUZAWA was ordered by the Nakatsu clan to open a school of Western studies in Edo, and recruited company from the alumni.

sen.j: 周吉は同行を希望、江戸へ下る原田磊蔵と三人連れで同年秋江戸に入る。
sen.e: In the autumn of the same year, Shukichi applied to the new school and moved to Edo with Yukichi and Raizo HARADA who already planned to go to Edo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Shukichi offered to go with him, and in the autumn of the same year went to Edo with Yukichi and Raizo HARADA who had already planned to go to Edo.
sen.cmt: 時制を直します。わかりやすくします。
sen.e: Shukichi offered to go with him, and in the autumn of the same year went to Edo with Yukichi and Raizo HARADA who had already planned to go to Edo.

sen.j: 築地鉄砲州（現在の明石町 (東京都中央区)）で諭吉と同居し諭吉が開いた蘭学塾「一小家塾」（後の慶應義塾）の第1期生となった。
sen.e: He lived with Yukichi in Teppozu, Tsukiji (now Akashicho [Chuo Ward, Tokyo Prefecture]) and became a member of the inaugural class in the school for Western studies called "Isshokajuku" (the predecessor of Keio Gijuku school).
sen.cmt: 「一小」読み方不明のため"Issho"にしました。一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He lived with Yukichi in Teppozu, Tsukiji (present Akashi-cho, Chuo Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) and became the first member of 'a small private school' of Western studies (the predecessor of Keio Gijuku) opened by Yukichi.
sen.cmt: 「一小家塾」は固有名詞ではなく、単に福沢がそのように書物に記しただけです。オリジナル著者は引用として括弧に入れていますが説明は不要だと思われます。
sen.e: He lived with Yukichi in Teppozu, Tsukiji (present Akashi-cho, Chuo Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) and became the first member of 'a small private school' of Western studies (the predecessor of Keio Gijuku) opened by Yukichi.

sen.j: 著書翻訳を相当数手掛けた。
sen.e: He then translated many books.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He then translated many books.
He then translated many books.

sen.j: 1860年（万延元年）、岡本博卿の名で訳した「万国政表」は日本統計学史上珍しい文献と言われ、オランダ語から訳された、日本最初の世界統計書とされる。
sen.e: A book called "Bankokuseihyo" which was written in Dutch and was translated by him under his pen name, Hirokimi OKAMOTO in 1860 was considered as the first world statistical book that was translated into Japanese, and it was one of the unique books in Japanese statistical history.
sen.cmt: 「博卿」読み方不明のため"Hirokimi"にしました
sen.e: In 1860 he translated a book "Bankoku Seihyo" under a pen name of Hakukei OKAMOTO, and this book is considered a very unique material in the history of Japanese statistical science and regarded as the first book in Japan gathering statistics of world and translated from Dutch.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: In 1860 he translated a book "Bankoku Seihyo" under a pen name of Hakukei OKAMOTO, and this book is considered a very unique material in the history of Japanese statistical science and regarded as the first book in Japan gathering statistics of world and translated from Dutch.

sen.j: 1871年（明治4年）12月、日本の中央統計機関として院表課が設立されたが「政表」の文字は既に古川によって使用されていた。
sen.e: In December 1871, Inhyo-ka section (the statistics section) was established as the Japanese central statistical authority, however the word "Seihyo" had been already used by FURUKAWA.
In December 1871, Inhyo-ka was established as central institution of statistics in Japan, however the word 'seihyo' had been already used by Furukawa.
In December 1871, Inhyo-ka was established as central institution of statistics in Japan, however the word 'seihyo' had been already used by Furukawa.

sen.j: 1868年（慶応4年）慶應義塾初代塾長に就任。
sen.e: In 1868, he became the first principal of Keio Gijuku school.
In 1868, he became the first president of Keio Gijuku.
In 1868, he became the first president of Keio Gijuku.

sen.j: しかし福澤の世話で幕府の旗本・古川家の養子となると名を古川節蔵と改めた。
sen.e: After he was adopted into the Furukawa family, a retainer of the Edo bakufu (the Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), with FUKUZA's recommendation he changed his name to Setsuzo FURUKAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: With Fukuzawa's recommendation, he was adopted into the Furukawa family, a retainer of the Edo bakufu (the Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and he changed his name to Setsuzo FURUKAWA.
sen.cmt: 固有名詞写し間違いがあります。
sen.e: With Fukuzawa's recommendation, he was adopted into the Furukawa family, a retainer of the Edo bakufu (the Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and he changed his name to Setsuzo FURUKAWA.

sen.j: 戦いを好まない諭吉が止めるも聞かず、旧幕府軍・榎本軍に加わる。
sen.e: He then joined the Enomoto's army that was on the bakufu side, although Yukichi, who didn't like wars, stopped him from joining the army.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He joined the Enomoto's army supporting the bakufu army, although a pacifist Yukichi had stopped him.
He joined the Enomoto's army supporting the bakufu army, although a pacifist Yukichi had stopped him.

sen.j: 明治維新、戊辰戦争時には榎本武揚らと共に函館市五稜郭に立て篭り新政府軍に抵抗。
sen.e: During the Meiji restoration and the Boshin War, he barricaded himself in Goryokaku (five-sided fortification) in Hakodate City and resisted the army of the new government with Takeaki ENOMOTO.
During the Meiji Restoration and the Boshin War, he barricaded himself in Goryokaku castle of Hakodate City with Takeaki ENOMOTO and other, and resisted the army of the new government.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: During the Meiji Restoration and the Boshin War, he barricaded himself in Goryokaku castle of Hakodate City with Takeaki ENOMOTO and other, and resisted the army of the new government.

sen.j: 幕府海軍に出仕して「軍艦高雄 (軍艦)」（第二回天）の艦長となる。
sen.e: He then joined the Edo bakufu navy (the Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and became captain of the "Gunkan Takao (warship)" (later named the Dainikaiten).
He then joined the navy of the bakufu and became captain of 'Gunkan Takao' (a warship, later used for the second Kaiten [suicide weapon of the imperial Japanese Navy in World War Ⅱ]).
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: He then joined the navy of the bakufu and became captain of 'Gunkan Takao' (a warship, later used for the second Kaiten [suicide weapon of the imperial Japanese Navy in World War Ⅱ]).

sen.j: 1869年（明治2年）には高雄艦長として宮古湾海戦に榎本武揚、土方歳三らと参加した。
sen.e: In 1869, he participated in the naval battle of Miyako Bay as the captain of the warship Takao with Takeaki ENOMOTO and Toshizo HIJIKATA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1869, he participated in the naval battle of Miyako Bay as the captain of the warship Takao with Takeaki ENOMOTO and Toshizo HIJIKATA.
In 1869, he participated in the naval battle of Miyako Bay as the captain of the warship Takao with Takeaki ENOMOTO and Toshizo HIJIKATA.

sen.j: しかし、途中暴風雨に遭い機関を損傷、速度が上がらず「ストーンウォール号（甲鉄）奪還作戦」の奇襲には参加出来ずに追撃された。
sen.e: However, he was unable to participate in a surprise attack known as the "Mission to regain the Warship Stone Wall" because his warship could not gain speed due to engine damage caused by a rainstorm that was encountered on the way to the mission and also his warship was later attacked.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, because his warship could not gain speed due to engine damage caused by a rainstorm on the way to mission, he was unable to participate in a surprise attack, the 'Mission to regain the warship Stonewall' (Stone wall was generally called Kotetsu-kan [ironclad]); and his warship was attacked.

However, because his warship could not gain speed due to engine damage caused by a rainstorm on the way to mission, he was unable to participate in a surprise attack, the 'Mission to regain the warship Stonewall' (Stone wall was generally called Kotetsu-kan [ironclad]); and his warship was attacked.

sen.j: 田野畑村沖羅賀浜へ座礁させ自沈。
sen.e: He was stranded and beached his warship on Raga beach in Tanohata Village.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Therefore he made the ship stranded on Raga Beach of Tanohata Village and sank it.
Therefore he made the ship stranded on Raga Beach of Tanohata Village and sank it.

sen.j: 高雄を捨て総員退去を命じ、上陸後降伏し新政府軍に捕えられた。
sen.e: He commanded all the crews to leave the warship Takao and was captured by the army of the new government after he surrendered on the beach.
He commanded all the crews to leave the warship Takao and was captured by the army of the new government after he surrendered on the beach.
He commanded all the crews to leave the warship Takao and was captured by the army of the new government after he surrendered on the beach.

sen.j: 言うことを聞かなかった節蔵だが、福澤諭吉はそれでも可愛がり、入牢した節蔵を何度も訪ね面倒をみた。
sen.e: Yukichi FUKUZAWA still cared for Setsuzo and visited him in jail many times to take care of him even though he didn't listen to Yukichi.
Yukichi FUKUZAWA still cared for Setsuzo and visited him in jail many times to take care of him, even though Setsuzo had ignored his advices and gone to the war.
sen.cmt: 時制を直します。わかりやすくします。
sen.e: Yukichi FUKUZAWA still cared for Setsuzo and visited him in jail many times to take care of him, even though Setsuzo had ignored his advices and gone to the war.

sen.j: その後許され今度は古川正雄と改名。
sen.e: He was later pardoned by the new government and then changed his name to Masao FURUKAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He was later pardoned by the new government and then changed his name to Masao FURUKAWA.
He was later pardoned by the new government and then changed his name to Masao FURUKAWA.

sen.j: 明治新政府の海軍や工部省に出仕し海軍兵学校 (日本)教官などを務めた。
sen.e: He then worked for the navy and the ministry of industries in the new Meiji government, and became an instructor at the Japanese navy school.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He served the new government of the Meiji era and worked for the navy and the ministry of industries and became instructor of Japanese Naval Academy.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: He served the new government of the Meiji era and worked for the navy and the ministry of industries and became instructor of Japanese Naval Academy.

sen.j: 1870年（明治3年）～1872年（明治5年）には、我が国最初の小学校教科書『絵入り智恵の輪』を発刊した。
sen.e: From 1870 to 1872, he published "The Puzzle Ring with Illustrations" which was the first textbook in primary school in Japan.
From 1870 to 1872, he published "Eiri Chie no Wa" (The Puzzle Ring with Illustrations) which was the first textbook in primary school in Japan.
From 1870 to 1872, he published "Eiri Chie no Wa" (The Puzzle Ring with Illustrations) which was the first textbook in primary school in Japan.

sen.j: この書物の中で日本で初めて「背広」という言葉を使用したと言われる。
sen.e: It believed that the word "Sebiro (business suit)" was used in Japan for the first time in his textbook.
It is said that the word 'sebiro' (business suit) was used in the book for the first time in Japan.
It is said that the word 'sebiro' (business suit) was used in the book for the first time in Japan.

sen.j: 1873年（明治6年）ウィーン万国博覧会開催に際し同地へ派遣された。
sen.e: In 1873, he was sent to Vienna where the Vienna International Exhibition was held.
In 1873, he was sent to Vienna where the Vienna International Exhibition was held.
In 1873, he was sent to Vienna where the Vienna International Exhibition was held.

sen.j: 1875年（明治8年）津田仙らと共に楽善舎を組織、盲聾唖者の教育を発起した。
sen.e: In 1875, he focused on education for people with visual and hearing difficulties and established a support group called Rakuzensha, with Sen TSUDA and others
sen.cmt: National School for blind attached to Tsukuba University
sen.e: In 1875, he focused on education for people with visual and hearing difficulties and established a support group called Rakuzensha, with Sen TSUDA and others
In 1875, he focused on education for people with visual and hearing difficulties and established a support group called Rakuzensha, with Sen TSUDA and others

sen.j: 中村正直、岸田吟香、山尾庸三、ヘンリー・フォールズらと東京盲亞学校（現筑波大学附属視覚特別支援学校）の前身・訓盲院を創設した。
sen.e: He then established the Training School for the Blind, that was the predecessor of the Tokyo School for the Blind and the Deaf (now the National School for the Blind, attached to Tsukuba University), with Masanao NAKAMURA, Ginko KISHIDA, Yozo YAMAO and Henry Faulds.

He then established Kunmoin (Training School for the Blind), the predecessor of the Tokyo School for the Blind and the Deaf (present School for the Visually Impaired of the Special Support Education, University of Tsukuba), with Masanao NAKAMURA, Ginko KISHIDA, Yozo YAMAO, Henry Faulds and others.
sen.cmt: 固有名詞ミスがあります。翻訳者の訳は恐らく古いファイルのものです。現在、筑波大学はUniversity of Tsukubaで統一、盲についてはvisually impairedで統一。
sen.e: He then established Kunmoin (Training School for the Blind), the predecessor of the Tokyo School for the Blind and the Deaf (present School for the Visually Impaired of the Special Support Education, University of Tsukuba), with Masanao NAKAMURA, Ginko KISHIDA, Yozo YAMAO, Henry Faulds and others.

sen.j: 晩年は失意の人として41歳の若さで病死した。
sen.e: He spent his last years in frustration and died at the young age of 41.
He spent his last years as a broken man and died from illness at the young age of 41.
He spent his last years as a broken man and died from illness at the young age of 41.

sen.j: 著作には他に『洋行漫筆』、『ちゑのいとぐち』、『絵入り智恵の環』などがある。
sen.e: His primary literary works include, "The Travel Essay in the West", "The Hints for Wisdom, "The Puzzle Ring with Illustrations".
His primary literary works include "Yoko Manpitsu" (The Travel Essay in the West), "Chie no Itoguchi" (The Hints for Wisdom) and "Eiri Chie no Wa."
His primary literary works include "Yoko Manpitsu" (The Travel Essay in the West), "Chie no Itoguchi" (The Hints for Wisdom) and "Eiri Chie no Wa."
